Futures dove in early trade and held those losses ahead of Tuesday's open, suffering significant drag from struggling markets overseas. Dow futures were 121 points in the hole. S&P 500 futures tumbled 16 points and Nasdaq 100 futures dropped 28.75 points. The stock market today continues to walk a tightrope between optimism toward a recovering economy and concern over the…
Stocks groaned lower in hectic early trade Wednesday, following the lead of global markets after China continued letting its currency fall in line with currency market influences.
The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average slumped 1.3% each. The S&P 500 dropped 1.2%.
Volume rose, up 8% on the Nasdaq and 3% higher on the NYSE, compared with volume levels at the same time Tuesday.

The stock market today launched with the S&P 500 tearing a hole in support at its 200-day moving average, around the 2075 level. The index took a quick breath of air above its 50-day line on Monday and Tuesday before dropping back into its repeated pattern of 200-day tests begun June 29. In that time the index has finished two sessions below that line of support, on July 8 and 9. The Nasdaq is trading just below its 50-day moving average.
U.S. economic news was relatively minor, with the Labor Department's June Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey narrowing to 5.24 million unfilled positions vs. 5.35 million open jobs in May.

New York Federal Reserve chief William Dudley, speaking in Rochester, N.Y., said it was early to judge what was going on in China, that the country's currency could have been appreciating alongside the dollar and in need of adjustment.
"Obviously if the Chinese economy is weaker than maybe what the Chinese authorities anticipated, it's probably not inappropriate for the currency to adjust in consequence to that weakness," he said.
The Energy Information Administration reports weekly oil inventories at 10:30 a.m. ET. The Treasury Department reports its July budget at 2 p.m.
The Dow opened almost unanimously lower. Only Chevron (CVX) rose, up 0.2%, aided by a 1% rebound in oil prices. Apple (AAPL), Nike (NKE), JPMorgan (JPM) and Boeing (BA) fell more than 2%.

On the S&P 500, Fossil (FOSL) and Yahoo (YHOO) were worst hit, down 5% each. Fossil reported weaker-than-expected Q2 revenue growth and Q3 guidance. Yahoo's drop is likely attributable to its 384 million share stake in Alibaba, which has said it will spin off at some point as a separately traded entity.

At the top of the S&P 500, banking and payment software technologies firm Fidelity National Information Services (FIS) jumped nearly 6% after announcing it would pay $9.1 billion to acquire SunGard Data Systems. The privately held SunGard had registered for an initial public offering in June. The company reported $4.67 billion debt as of June 30. National reported that the cash-stock deal would create a company with $9.2 billion in combined revenue. Wednesday's gain hoisted shares to just below a 68.99 buy point in a shallow, five-month cup base.

China-based e-retail giant Alibaba (BABA) retreated 7% in opening trade after its second-quarter earnings narrowly topped expectations, while a 28% revenue jump stopped short of projections and the growth of total gross volume slowed to 34%. Management launched a two-year, $4.6 billion share buyback initiative. The loss put shares 40% below their November high and 6% above their September IPO price.

Among leaders, Ambarella (AMBA), a leading developer of video processing chips, skidded 4% lower, to the bottom of the IBD 50 list. Key client GoPro (GPRO) was also 4% lower in early trade. Stocks were steady, trimming only slightly their early losses at midday Wednesday.
The Nasdaq was down 0.3% and off early lows. The Dow Jones industrial average kept a 0.6% slip and the S&P 500 was off 0.4%.

The stock market today saw the Nasdaq still in positive territory so far this week, while the S&P 500 and the Dow slipped into the red. Volume remained mixed, down 2% on the Nasdaq and 9% higher on the NYSE, compared to action at the same time Tuesday. Losses were broad, with almost 450 of the S&P 500 stocks and 90% of IBD's 197 industry groups declining in morning trade.

Tenet Healthcare (THC) surged 3% in very heavy trade after CEO Trevor Fetter detailed to news sources plans to double the company's footprint in Texas. The Affordable Care Act pointed to better results for hospitals in states including Texas, California and Florida, which have large numbers of uninsured consumers. Tenet announced Tuesday it had completed its $1.8 billion acquisition of Vanguard Health Systems.
Tenet's gain broke the stock free of its converged 10- and 40-week moving averages. It is climbing the right side of a five-month consolidation.
On the IBD 50 list, Priceline.com (PLCN) punched up 2% to take a new high in heavy trade. The online travel deals broker is 7% past a 994.10 buy point after clearing a late-stage flat base Sept. 18.

IBD 50 stock Noah Holdings (NOAH) climbed 3% in very strong trade. The China-based investment products and services provider has staged a volatile, 12-month advance. It is climbing the right side of a deep, V-shaped cup with a potential buy point at 18.78.

Evercore Partners (EVR) dropped 3%, the hardest hit among IBD 50 stocks. The stock is holding just above support at its 10-week moving average, and just below a 52.90 buy point in a three weeks tight pattern.

Tenet Healthcare (THC) reported a 7% jump in revenue Tuesday, its highest gain in several years, as outpatient visits grew. Hospital operator earnings have been on the uptick as more patients are able to pay for services under ObamaCare. The operator of 49 hospitals in 11 states said fourth-quarter earnings were 52 cents per share, under analyst estimates of 68…

In good times or bad, people will still need to visit their doctor, take medication and treat acute and long-term illnesses. So medical stocks tend to do well in choppy markets as demand remains constant.

Medical-related stocks dominate IBD's Bolting RS Lines Screen Of The Day. The RS line measures a stock's performance vs. the benchmark S&P 500. Smart investors should be watching the Relative Strength line to see leaders who are breaking out ahead of the market and not just following a general uptrend.
Here are the top five medical stocks on the Screen Of The Day:

Santarus (SNTS) had only four products on the market last quarter: two diabetes drugs, an acid-reflux treatment and a cholesterol drug. But the company managed to beat analyst expectations as a court ruled it could keep its patent on its Zegerid acid reflux drug. Shares popped 11% on March 5 and continued climbing. The stock hit a record intraday high of 17.94 Monday before closing down 8 cents to 17.50 on the stock market. Santarus' RS line hit a new high along with the stock. It has kept rising as Santarus outpaces the broader market rally.

Tenet Healthcare (THC) runs 49 hospitals in 11 states, mostly in rural areas. In February the Tenet reported a 7% rise in revenue, its best gain in years as outpatient visits grew. But both earnings and revenue failed to meet analyst exceptions. Tenet shares rose nearly 3% to a 7 1/2-year high Monday.
Tenet's RS line is also mirroring its accelerating stock action.

Universal Health Services (UHS) operates 25 acute care hospitals and 198 behavioral health care centers in 36 states. On March 1, Universal Health reported better-than-expected earnings growth. Universal Health's RS line has been on the uptick closely mirroring the stock's steady rise.

Hospital stocks like Tenet and Universal Health have been up since President Obama's re-election as ObamaCare is viewed as a positive for hospitals. The Medical-Hospital group is highly ranked at No. 6 out of the 197 industry groups IBD covers.
Universal Health leads the group with a Composite Rating of 98, meaning it's in the top 2% of stocks covered based on key metrics, such as sales and profit growth. Tenet is No. 2 with a 97 ranking.
Biogen Idec (BIIB) has been rising in recent months on positive drug trial news and government approval.

On Feb. 8, the biotech released positive trial data on its late-stage hemophilia candidate. Last week an EU advisory committee, the Committee for Medicinal Products for Human Use, voted to approve Biogen's multiple-sclerosis drug Tecfidera. EU regulators must give final approval. Over in the U.S., the FDA is expected to give its decision on the drug Thursday.

Team Health Holdings (TMH) rounds out the top five. The company provides outsourced health care staffing for 800 clients in the U.S. Team Health closed at a new high of 36.16 on Monday after clearing a short consolidation last week.

The major indexes opened in tightly mixed formation Friday, as consumer sentiment data provided a lift but Q1 GDP data dragged on the early trading. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.2%, aided by Hewlett-Packard's (HPQ) 3% advance. The Nasdaq slumped 0.2% and the S&P 500 split the difference with a fractional loss. Volume was down 14% on the Nasdaq…

A number of consumer-related stocks hit new highs Thursday on data that showed retail sales rose more than expected in May and initial jobless claims fell last week. Restoration Hardware (RH) rose 3% in double-paced volume during the regular session and was up sharply in post-session trading after a better-than-expected quarterly earnings report. The high-end home furnishings retailer posted profit…

Buyers remained in control and stocks held near highs with about two and a half hours left to go in Monday's session. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 flirted with all-time highs after the Nasdaq hit a new 52-week high earlier in the session. The Nasdaq outperformed, rising 1%. The S&P 500 added 0.8%, just off its all-time…

Tenet Healthcare (THC) shares soared after it reported earnings above analyst estimates on Wednesday. Hospitals are up broadly after President Obama was re-elected, good news for the Affordable Care Act.Tenet Healthcare, the operator of 40 hospitals in 11 states, said Q3 earnings were 37 cents per share vs. 5 cents in 2011, beating estimates by 3 cents. Revenue rose 4.8% to $2.2 billion, in line with analyst views.Per patient revenue rose 3.7% to $11,579. Adjusted admissions increased 1.4%. Outpatient surgeries continued to grow, rising 6.3%. Total emergency department visits increased by 4.9%.Tenet shares surged 10%. Vanguard Health Systems (VHS) shares climbed 9%. HCA Holdings (HCA) shares leapt 8%. Universal Health Services (UHS) shares gained 5%."Last night's election results are encouraging for the full implementation of the Affordable Care Act," CEO Trevor Fetter said on a conference call according to Reuters.President Obama's re-election is good news for hospital stocks. If Mitt Romney had been elected, the Affordable Care Act would have been on the chopping blocks.The act, nicknamed ObamaCare, will expand coverage to people that are unable to qualify for coverage currently. Under the act hospitals will treat fewer patients that can't pay, helping boost their bottom line. More people could visit the doctor if they knew they could afford care.The Medical-Hospitals group is ranked No. 47 out of Investor's Business Daily's 197 groups and is the best preforming group Wednesday.

Health Management Associates (HMA) gave preliminary first-quarter guidance late Tuesday that was far below Wall Street forecasts, sending hospital stocks falling in after hours trading. The hospital operator says it likely earned 12-13 cents a share adjusted in Q1 ended March 31. Analysts had expected 24 cents. HMA cut its full-year EPS target to 86-95 cents from 86 cents-$1.01. Analysts…

One way to gauge the strength of big-cap stocks is to see how they are trading vs. their 10-week moving average lines. The 10-week moving average calculates a stock's average closing price over the past 10 weeks. When plotted on a weekly chart, one can get a quick read on the stock's price trend over the past 2-1/2 months. When…
Investors will look to see whether Health Management Associates (HMA) and LifePoint Hospitals (LPNT) have found a prescription for profits as they announce fourth-quarter results this week.
Both hospital companies have seen profits fall and are forecast to report lower earnings per share amid rising commodity costs and other expenses.
Still, shares of both are trading near 52-week highs and well above 50-day and 200-day averages.
Health Management, whose shares hit an 18-month high Friday, will report Thursday after the market closes.
The consensus of 10 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for Q4 EPS to fall 31% to 18 cents and for revenue to climb 6.3% to $1.68 billion.

The hospital operator last Wednesday announced a definitive agreement to buy an 80% controlling interest in Bayfront Health System in St. Petersburg, Fla. After the transaction concludes, Health Management will operate a total 71 hospitals with about 11,000 beds throughout the U.S.
Since Dec. 19, share price has surged about 43%. It boasts a near-best 98 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed 98% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth.
Health Management was down about 1.1% in Monday afternoon trading on the stock market today.
LifePoint Hospitals, a spinoff of hospital giant HCA Holdings (HCA), is slated to report Friday before the market opens.
HCA, along with biotech Celgene (CELG) and medical equipment maker ResMed (RMD), hit a 52-week high the first week of February. HCA has faded a bit since then.
The outlook for LifePoint is for EPS to fall 17% to 65 cents, and revenue to slide 6% to $861.7 million
LifePoint could be impacted this year by a section of the Affordable Care Act, or ObamaCare, that penalize hospitals with high rates of readmissions for Medicare patients.
Because of its high exposure to Medicare, LifePoint could face penalties this year in the form of lower Medicare reimbursements, according to the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services, or CMS.

Last Thursday, LifePoint named a new chief medical officer, Russell Holman, replacing Lanny Copeland, who retired. Holman stepped into the post Monday, although Copeland will assist during a transition period.
Like Health Management, LifePoint consolidated for most of 2012.
LifePoint slid 0.7% in Monday afternoon trading, but was about 28% higher than an intraday low of 34.37 on Oct. 31.

Elsewhere in the Medical-Hospitals group, ranked a lofty No. 3 on IBD's list of 197 industry groups, HCA and Universal Health Services (UHS) were down more than 1.3% and Tenet Healthcare (THC) declined 0.8%.Investors will look to see whether Health Management Associates (HMA) and LifePoint Hospitals (LPNT) have found a prescription for profits as they announce fourth-quarter results this week.Both hospital companies have seen profits fall and are forecast to report lower earnings per share amid rising commodity costs and other expenses.Still, shares of both are trading near 52-week highs and well above 50-day and 200-day averages.Health Management, whose shares hit an 18-month high Friday, will report Thursday after the market closes.The consensus of 10 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for Q4 EPS to fall 31% to 18 cents and for revenue to climb 6.3% to $1.68 billion.The hospital operator last Wednesday announced a definitive agreement to buy an 80% controlling interest in Bayfront Health System in St. Petersburg, Fla. Stocks inched higher in soft trade at Friday's open as markets watched for signs of progress in Washington. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.3%. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 each drifted 0.2% higher. Volume was sharply lower in the stock market today, down 26% on the Nasdaq and 6% lower on the NYSE compared with the same time…

Stocks forged higher Wednesday, with most of the gains appearing after the Fed's policy announcement and the press conference by Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke. When the closing bell rang, the Nasdaq rose 0.8%, while the S&P 500 and the NYSE composite each climbed 0.6%. Advancers beat decliners by about 8-to-5 on both major exchanges. Volume rose on the NYSE, but fell a tad on the Nasdaq, according to early data.The Fed's statement and the press conference gave most investors the impression that a rate hike is the furthest thing from Ben Bernanke's mind.Hospitals, one of the market's weaker groups, won the day's biggest gains, driven by an 11% rise by Universal Health Services (UHS) and a 4% rise by Health Management Associates  (HMA).Gold and silver miners, a healthy group, also enjoyed strong bids, buoyed by sharp increases in bullion prices.Other highly ranked groups that scored solid gains include biotechs, cable and satellite equipment makers, software database companies and clothing manufacturers.Amazon's (AMZN) 7% surge boosted the Internet retailers, a middle-of-the-pack group.

The market is in a confirmed uptrend, with hospitals and biotechs leading the way to new highs. IBD's Relative Strength line measures how a stock is performing vs. the S&P 500 index. These tend to be leading stocks, rather than followers, especially in an uptrend.
Here are the top medical related stocks on IBD's Bolting RS Line Screen Of The Day:

Celgene (CELG) closed at a new high of 97.67 on Monday. That followed a 17% surge last week to a new high thanks to its bullish guidance at an investors conference last week. The biotech expects annual revenue to more than double to $12 billion by 2017 and that its psoriasis drug candidate Apremilast met expectations in its phase-three trials.
The stock's RS line also spiked to new highs along with the share price.
Celgene also is ranked No. 1 in the latest Big Cap 20.

The Medicines Co. (MDCO) hit a five-year closing high of 29.26 on Friday after the biotech said it was purchasing Incline Therapeutics for $185 million, plus up to $205 million if it achieves regulatory approval targets.

Shares broke out of a consolidation from the start of 2013, then jumped nearly 12% on Jan. 8 after Medicines Co. said its anti-clotting drug cangrelor produced positively results in a late-stage clinical trial. Medicines Co. says it plans to file for approval of cangrelor this year and launch the drug in 2014.
Tenet Healthcare (THC), a hospital chain that operates in 11 states, closed at a new closing high of 34.68 on Monday.

The hospital group is highly ranked at No. 30 out of the 197 industry groups IBD covers. Credit a combination of robust hospital earnings growth — Tenet itself reported a 300% EPS gain on Nov. 7 — and Pres. Obama's re-election. That means his landmark health care reform will go forward, expanding coverage by some 30 million in January 2014. With more people able to pay for health care, hospitals are expected to see a drop in bad debt expenses.

HCA Holdings (HCA), the nation's largest hospital operator, also closed at a new high of 33.85 on Monday. HCA is ranked No. 2 on the Big Cap 20 list. The RS line was at new highs ahead of the stock's move earlier this month from a three-month consolidation.

Alkermes (ALKS), an Irish biotech, reached a six-year closing high on Monday. The stock has soared more than 19% already in 2013 thanks to positive results from a phase one study of its new antipsychotic candidate, ALKS 3831.

Universal Health Services (UHS) rounds out the list. It operates psychiatric facilities and acute-care hospitals. The company closed at a year-high of 51.52 on Monday. Universal Health's RS line was trading at or near new highs ahead of the stock's Dec. 18 breakout.

Earnings season has been in swing for several weeks, but it's not over yet. Thursday brings quarterly reports from four companies on the elite IBD 50 list of the very best stocks based on fundamental and technical factors. Ocwen Financial (OCN), Catamaran (CTRX) and Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) report before the market open. Universal Health Services (UHS) is due after the…

It's cliche to say "best of the best." But when you start with the IBD 50 list of top performing stocks, then find five that are doing even better, that's really what you're talking about. Today's Screen Of The Day is Bolting Relative Strength Lines. The RS line measures a stock's performance vs. the benchmark S&P 500. Here are the…

The number of new 52-week highs greatly shrank Wednesday as the market took a beating. But hospital stocks bucked the sell-off as President Obama's victory marked a victory for the Affordable Care Act and companies that stand to benefit from it. It's expected that with more Americans insured, hospital operators will treat fewer patients that can't pay their bills. Tenet…

Stocks meandered to a mixed close amid lower volume Tuesday, as the market seemed to brace for results Wednesday of the Fed's much-awaited policy meeting and key earnings reports. The Nasdaq edged higher 0.1%, while the S&P 500 dipped 0.1% and the Dow Jones industrial average ceded 0.3%. Volume fell by a hair on the Nasdaq, and by 4% on…
Stocks staged a big comeback to finish mixed on Monday. Worries over the European debt crisis, a strong dollar and worse-than-expected factory data had pressured equities for most of the session.

The Nasdaq outperformed with a 0.3% gain. Chip issues were one bright spot. The Philadelphia semiconductor index climbed 1.6%. OmniVision Technologies (OVTI) and Cree (CREE) rose 5% and 4%, respectively.
Meanwhile, the Dow and S&P 500 ticked up 0.1% each. The NYSE composite fell 0.2% after having been down over 2%. Volume fell on both exchanges.

Portfolio Recovery Associates (PRAA) rallied 4% to a record high. The stock extended its win streak to six sessions. Portfolio Recovery found support near its 50-day moving average May 7. In late April, the debt collector beat views with a 38% gain in Q1 earnings.
Netflix (NFLX) advanced 6% in nearly twice its average volume. The stock retraced the bulk of Friday's downgrade-inspired decline.

Hibbett Sports (HIBB) rose 4% in almost double its average turnover. The stock found support at its 50-day moving average Friday. Hibbett reports earnings Friday. The sporting goods retailer is slated to earn 47 cents a share, up 24%. Sales are expected to rise 11% to $174.8 million.

After the close, Agilent Technologies (A) reported fiscal Q2 earnings of 43 cents a share, up 231% and 2 cents above estimates. Sales also topped views. The company gave an upbeat outlook for Q3 profit and revenue. But shares fell in extended trading.
Earnings out Tuesday include Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF), Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), Home Depot (HD), Kirkland's (KIRK) and TJX Cos. (TJX)
Data on housing starts, building permits and producer prices will also be out Tuesday.
U.S. Stocks End Mixed After Erasing Most Of Their Losses
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks bounced back from big losses and closed mixed on Monday. Most indexes rose for the first time in three sessions.
The Nasdaq rose 0.3% after having been down 1.8%. The Dow and the S&P 500 edged up 0.1% each. The NYSE composite fell 0.2%, well above an earlier 2.1% deficit. Volume fell on both major exchanges.
School operators and some retail groups were among the day's best performers. Energy and machinery were some of the worst areas as crude futures fell.
U.S. Stocks Push Off Lows
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks continued to improve in late trading Monday. Most indexes have recouped more than half of their earlier losses.

The NYSE composite fell 1%, the S&P 500 0.7% and the Dow 0.6%. And the Nasdaq fell a milder 0.5%, thanks in part to support from chip issues. The Philadelphia semiconductor index climbed 0.6%. Volume was again tracking lower on both exchanges.

Bucyrus International (BUCY) turned lower and dropped 5%, despite an upgrade. Earlier Monday, Robert W. Baird raised the mining equipment maker to outperform from neutral, citing its recent acquisition of Terex as a positive.

Cbeyond (CBEY) reversed opening losses and rose 3% to near a 52-week high. The stock is on track to extend its win streak to six sessions. Cbeyond provides communications and IT services. Its earnings grew 50% and 200% in the latest two quarters, but analysts are expecting a small loss in the current period.

Agilent Technologies (A) rose a fraction in seesaw trading. Earlier Monday, the Federal Trade Commission approved Agilent's buyout of Varian (VARI) . It won approval from European regulators in January. Agilent, which makes scientific equipment, also reports fiscal Q2 results after the close.
U.S. Stocks Work Off More Losses
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks continued to improve from their worst levels in afternoon trading Monday.
The NYSE composite was down 1.5%, the Dow and S&P 500 1.2% each. The Nasdaq gave up 1.1%. All had been down between 1.6% and 2.1% at session lows. Volume was again tracking lower across the board.
June gold settled at $1,227.30 an ounce, down 50 cents. It edged slightly higher in afternoon trading. Crude trimmed losses and hovered just below $70 a barrel.

Given Imaging (GIVN) erased opening gains and tumbled 9% to a two-month low. The stock also neared its 200-day moving average, which it's been trading above for 10 months. On Friday, the medical equipment maker delivered Q1 earnings well above views, but sales missed estimates.

Bridgepoint Education (BPI) reversed lower and fell 6% to a two-month low. The school operator has delivered triple-digit earnings growth for the past seven quarters. But growth is slated to slow to 32% in the current period.
Silver Wheaton (SLW) also turned tail, falling 4% in heavy trading. The stock retraced Friday's advance.

On the upside, Akamai Technologies (AKAM) climbed 4% in fast trade. Despite the recent market sell-off, the stock sits only 2% off its 52-week high. Akamai's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has improved to C from D- earlier this month.
U.S. Stocks Trim Losses
BY VINCENT MAO
After sliding to new session lows, stocks pared some losses in early-afternoon trading Monday.
The NYSE composite was down 1.7% after falling as much as 2.1%. The Dow and S&P 500 shed 1.3% each. The Nasdaq gave up 1.2%. Turnover was again tracking lower on both major exchanges.
Oil fell below $70 a barrel on worries that the European debt crisis would hurt economic growth. Gold fell $2.90 to $1,224.90 an ounce, reversing early gains.
Chinese ADRs were among the hardest-hit after the Shanghai composite tumbled 5% to a one-year low.
Yanzhou Coal (YZC) gapped below its 50-day moving average and fell 6% in fast trade. It broke out on April 29, then triggered the 8% sell rule four sessions later.
VanceInfo Technologies (VIT) lost 6% and neared its May 5 low. The China-based outsourcer fell in each of the previous three weeks. It remains below its 50-day line.

China Automotive Systems (CAAS) erased opening gains and shed 4%. Earlier Monday, Oppenheimer started coverage of the maker of power-steering systems with an outperform rating. It too is beneath its 50-day line.
Meanwhile, Priceline (PCLN) fell 4% in brisk volume. The stock breached its 200-day moving average for the first time since March 31, 2009. Priceline has fallen 27% from its April 29 peak.
U.S. Stocks Hit Session Lows At Midday
BY JONAH KERI
The major indexes fell to intraday lows in quiet volume at midday Monday.

The Dow and S&P 500 fell 0.6% each, while the NYSE composite shed 0.9% and the Nasdaq dropped 0.5%. Volume dipped across the board. It sank 16% on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq compared with the same period Friday.

Alliance Data Systems (ADS) rose 3% in nearly twice its normal trade. The provider of consumer data packages to financial companies and other firms is rebounding after testing its 50-day moving average last week.

Hibbett Sports (HIBB) also advanced 3% in rapid volume. The athletic apparel and footwear vendor also found support at its 50-day line last week. The stock sports a 95 IBD Composite Rating and an A+ Group Relative Strength Rating.

On the downside, Lowe's (LOW) sank 4% in nearly five times its usual turnover. The home improvement chain posted a first-quarter profit of 34 cents a share. That's up from 32 cents a share the prior year. Revenue rose 4.7%, handily beating views. According to Thomson Reuters, analysts expected the company to earn 31 cents a share.
U.S. Stocks Turn Mixed Amid Euro Fears

The current list includes seven companies that will report fourth quarter earnings this week, giving investors a chance to take a closer look at the current performance of these top growth stocks. HCA Holdings (HCA) is buying back 80.8 million shares from Bank of America (BAC) for almost two-thirds the price of its IPO in March.

The hospital operator is paying about $1.5 billion, or $18.61 a share, for the 15.6% stake. BofA was a lead underwriter of HCA's IPO and obtained the stake when it acquired Merrill Lynch, which invested about $1 billion in 2006.
But the bank is now selling off noncore assets to raise capital.

Shares of HCA jumped more than 10%, though they're still down more than 30% from the IPO pricing of $30. BofA and rival hospital operators Tenet Healthcare (THC), Universal Health Services (UHS) and Community Health Systems (CYH) were rallying as well.
Three HCA board members representing BofA will step down, and the repurchase is expected to close Sept. 21.

Earlier this week, HCA backed its full-year growth forecast for cash flow, but its second-quarter earnings were hurt by higher admissions of low-income Medicaid patients and lower reimbursements on elderly Medicare patients. Tenet cited similar trends when it trimmed its cash flow forecast.

While BofA is getting $1.5 billion for selling the HCA shares, it has received a total of $3 billion on the stake when dividends and IPO proceeds are also included, giving it an overall gain of $2 billion.
The bank has been rushing to raise capital and save money to quell investor fears that it doesn't have enough money to cover mortgage-related claims and expenses.

BofA is selling off credit card businesses, recently unloaded half its stake in a Chinese bank, and sold $5 billion in shares to Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA). Tenet Healthcare (THC) said more poor patients and smaller reimbursements for elderly patients have forced it to trim its full-year cash flow forecast.

The No. 3 hospital operator said admissions of patients on Medicaid, a healthcare program for the poor, rose 5.5% in the third quarter so far. Reimbursements for patients on Medicare, a program for the elderly, were also below average in July and August.
Shares dropped 8% as of 2:20 p.m. ET. Rivals HCA Holdings  (HCA), Universal Health Services (UHS) and Community Health Systems (CYH) were down too.

HCA backed its full-year growth forecast on a similar cash flow measure, known as earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. But patient trends similar to the ones Tenet cited hurt its second-quarter earnings.
Tenet started cutting costs in August in anticipation of the less favorable mix of patients, and it expects those efforts to start paying off in the fourth quarter.
But the trends among hospital operators contrast with those seen among managed care companies, which have been benefitting from lower usage of services.
While the weak economy has sent more people to seek help from government health programs, it's prompted people still on commercial plans to save money by going to the doctor less often.

Insurers UnitedHealth Group  (UNH) and Aetna (AET) were down slightly, while WellPoint (WLP) edged up.Tenet Healthcare (THC) said more poor patients and smaller reimbursements for elderly patients have forced it to trim its full-year cash flow forecast.The No. 3 hospital operator said admissions of patients on Medicaid, a healthcare program for the poor, rose 5.5% in the third quarter so far. A correction is no time to buy stocks. Roughly three of every four stocks will fall. The disciplined investor won't fight those odds.
Yet, it's worth studying the stocks that are rising despite the correction. If fundamentally strong, they probably belong on a watch list.
Advertising middleman DG Fast Channel (DGIT) has jumped more than 15% during this correction. It broke out of a square-box base in February. Since then, it's revisited its 10-week line twice.
A third trip to the 10-week line isn't a sound buying area. So it's better if this stock forms a base or a three-weeks-tight pattern.
Its Composite Rating is a best-possible 99.

Hospital operator Universal Health Services (UHS) has risen more than 10% during the market correction. It's near a 52-week high but shows no sign of building a base yet. The stock has pulled back to its 10-week line twice already since a March breakout.
Boston Beer (SAM) has also added more than 10% during the correction. It's at a 52-week high after finding support at its 10-week line.
China-based Home Inns & Hotels Management (HMIN) has tacked on about 5% during the correction. It's building a base. The Composite Rating is 99.
Virtualization software provider VMware (VMW) also has gained about 5% during the correction. The stock is at a 52-week high after finding support at its 10-week line. The Composite Rating is 98.

Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance (ULTA) has risen about 5% during the correction. It's shaped a square box, as part of a base-on-base. The Obama administration's delay of implementation of a key provision of ObamaCare until 2015 drove hospital stocks lower in trading Wednesday.

The government late Tuesday delayed a provision that would fine employers next year for failing to offer sufficient health coverage. The move came after public and private employers, faced with a steep hike in costs to implement the provision, have cut jobs and work hours.
Hospital stocks had risen sharply in anticipation of swelling numbers of patients amid mandated insurance coverage.
Health Management Associates (HMA), which operates 70 acute care hospitals, fell 3% in midday trading on the stock market today.
Health Management shares had popped 87% this year, from an 8.76 low on Jan. 9 to an all-time high 16.41 on June 18, before it consolidated.
Tenet Healthcare (THC), which was also up sharply for the year, fell 5.6% in triple normal volume.
Community Health System (CYH) was off 3%, HCA Holdings (HCA) down 4.6% and Universal Health Services (UHS) slid 3.8%.
Meanwhile, health insurers were mixed Wednesday afternoon. They're generally expected to rise after delay of the key provision, which would increase costs as more insured people use health resources.
UnitedHealth Group (UNH) was up 0.3%. The nation's largest health insurer retreated from an all-time high 66.36 on Monday.

UnitedHealth said Tuesday that it would leave California's individual health insurance market by the end of this year, the second big insurer to exit ahead of major changes under ObamaCare. The move will force its 8,000 customers to find new coverage.
It was preceded by No. 3 health insurer Aetna (AET), which left the state's individual insurance market last month, affecting about 50,000 policyholders.
Aetna was down 0.5% Wednesday morning.

Elsewhere in the group, WellPoint (WLP), the No. 2 insurer, fell 0.3%. Cigna (CI) rose 0.2% and Humana (HUM) edged down less than 1%.The Obama administration's delay of implementation of a key provision of ObamaCare until 2015 drove hospital stocks lower in trading Wednesday.The government late Tuesday delayed a provision that would fine employers next year for failing to offer sufficient health coverage. Mastering something you know how to do well is hard enough. Learning a skill that doesn't come naturally is tougher. Either way, with hard work and practice, you can find your passion.• Accept your limits. Sheryl Roush, CEO of Sparkle Presentations, a firm specializing in keynote speeches and workplace communication training, started out owning a publishing business. She had difficulty giving employees feedback and didn't know exactly how to improve. Then someone at a networking event suggested she check out Toastmasters, a nonprofit organization developing public speaking and leadership skills. San Diego-based Roush says even though she was terrified to talk in front of strangers, she gave it a try.• Leap. Roush, now an accredited speaker of Toastmasters, hardly started out that way. "I had no idea how bad and ineffective I was," she told IBD. "I was totally unaware of the lack of credibility I had."In her first speech, she uttered 19 uhs and ums in six minutes.• Keep at it. Things didn't pick up immediately. "My first three speeches, I still cried nervously before each one," Roush said.Still, she kept getting up there week after week until she slowly became more confident. "I did a lot of practice, and it was done in the safety net of club," she said. "(Toastmasters) gives you instant feedback, with support to change as fast as you would like to."• Be brave. "Believe that you can do it, even if it's not going to be perfect," Roush said. "Do the best you can, every presentation."Roush's drive paid off. Only six months after her first Toastmasters meeting, she was paid to give a college commencement speech. Now her resume shows thousands of speeches in nine countries."I went from having no confidence or self-esteem to finding my true calling," she said.• Tap interests. For Dilip Abayasekara, an industrial scientist, public speaking was only a hobby. Then he got better."One of the things I learned was how to read an audience and adapt presentations to the audience," he said.Harrisburg, Pa.-based Abayasekara spoke to different audiences as a requirement to become an accredited Toastmaster speaker.That forced him to tailor his message to various groups: professionals, blue-collar workers, seniors, youth."In order to be effective, get the message across and connect, you have to know where your audience comes from, their expectations and how they view things," he said. "The more you know about the audience, the more you can adapt. It's not about the speaker; it's about the audience."• Find your voice. Growing up in Sri Lanka, Abayasekara saw public speakers as those who stood on a box and proclaimed a message to the crowd. "I thought I had to be an orator and shout out my message," he said.He realized the image was outdated, that what people want today is someone to converse with them."Nowadays, a good communicator has conversations with the audience one person at a time," he said. "I learned to speak from my heart and really connect with people."• Share knowledge. Abayasekara ran workshops where he worked on his own at lunchtime. "This was for sheer joy of it," he said.Managers saw it as beneficial, as employees would speak up more during meetings.So Abayasekara's boss asked him to coach scientists and engineers for their presentations. He also presented at seminars and conferences for the company and eventually served as Toastmasters' president.
5:15 p.m. Update:  The Nasdaq lost another skirmish with its 200-day moving average, but lower volume let the indexes avoid a distribution day.
Volume was about 1% lower on the Nasdaq and 11% down on NYSE. The Nasdaq closed below its 200-day line after three days above it. The area has served as resistance for more than a year.
Gold-mining stocks were among the strongest performers of the day. The metal ores group rose for a fourth-straight session.
The consumer electronics group was among the day's worst performers.
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Close Sharply Lower But Volume Falls
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
Stocks closed off session lows, but still with sharp losses.
The Nasdaq slid 1.9%, the S&P 500 1.8%, the Dow and NYSE composite 1.5%. But preliminary figures showed volume was lower, lessening the impact of the selling.
The Dow undercut its May low, while the other major indexes held above theirs. Despite a broad decline, relative few leading stocks fell in strong volume.
Steel, machinery, transportation and other industrials stocks fared worst in a broad decline.
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Scrape Intraday Lows In Slow Trade
BY PAUL WHITFIELD
Stocks scraped along intraday lows as volume remained off Wednesday's pace.
The Nasdaq led the retreat with a 2.8% dive. The S&P 500 and the Dow skidded 2.6% and 2.3%, respectively. The NYSE composite was down 2.4%.
The Philadelphia semiconductor index reeled 3.7%. Until today, it had risen for three straight sessions.
Volume was down 15% on the NYSE and 1% on the Nasdaq compared with the same time yesterday.
Losses were broad. Of IBD's 197 industry groups, only 10 were up. The winners included gold miners, computer data storage and career schools.
Two of those groups benefited from a single component that was up sharply.
In data storage, low-ranked Data Domain (DDUP) rocketed 34% to 24.03 in more than 12 times its usual trade on a takeover bid.
After Wednesday's close, NetApp (NTAP) announced that it would buy Data Domain for $25 a share.
NetApp rose 0.48 to 17.82 in more than triple its usual trade. It carries a mediocre Composite Rating of 77. Analysts have speculated that NetApp itself may be bought by Hewlett-Packard (HPQ).
Among career schools, Bridgepoint Education (BPI) jumped 28% in wild and huge trade. It reported a 116% increase in sales and a 163% pop in earnings. It launched its initial public offering April 15.
2:15 p.m. Update: Volume Dips, But Losses Expand
BY PAUL WHITFIELD
Stocks dug a deeper hole in afternoon trade, but volume dropped under Wednesday's pace.
If the slower trade continues, the indexes could duck a distribution day.
A distribution day is defined as a significant loss in heavier volume than the previous session. It points to institutional selling.
The Nasdaq was down 2.2%, slipping under its 200-day moving average. The S&P 500 was off 1.8% while the NYSE composite and the Dow fell 1.7%.
Volume was down 16% on the NYSE and 1% on the Nasdaq.
While more top-ranked stocks were falling than rising in fast trade, the gold-mining industry group was on track for a fourth consecutive gain.
The fundamentals in the group are patchy, but many of the stocks have either cleared bases or are near completing bases.
Only two stocks in the group have EPS Ratings of 94 or better; Yamana Gold (AUY) and Iamgold (IAG). Both recently cleared bases but are trading below $12 a share.
1:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Still Sag, But Volume Eases
BY PAUL WHITFIELD
Volume tailed off in midday trade as the indexes struggled to avoid another distribution day.
The Nasdaq was down 2.1%. The S&P 500 and the Dow trimmed 1.6%. The NYSE composite slid 1.4%.
Volume was up about 2% on the Nasdaq after being up as much as 12% earlier in the session. Trade on the NYSE was about 14% off Wednesday's pace.
Few top-ranked stocks were up in big trade.
One exception was Buckle (BKE). It rumbled 1.52 higher to 34.35 in double its routine trade. The teen-oriented retailer beat analysts' estimates but remains 22% off its 52-week high.
Far more top-ranked stocks were down in fast trade  not a good sign.

They included NewMarket (NEU), Advance Auto Parts (AAP), Universal Health Services (UHS), Cubic (CUB), Longtop Financial Technologies (LFT), Sociedad Quimica y Minera (SQM), Nustar Group Holdings (NSH), Concho Resources (CXO) and Quality Systems (QSII).
12:15 p.m. Update: Market Remains Sharply Lower At Midday
BY JONAH KERI
Stocks continued to struggle Thursday, as a decline in U.S. stocks followed the lead of foreign markets.
The Nasdaq sank 1.9%, while the Dow, S&P 500 and NYSE composite all fell 1.7%. The small-cap S&P 600 slipped 2%.
Volume was mixed. It eased 10% on the NYSE and swelled 6% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Wednesday.

Universal Health Services (UHS) slid 5% in more than three times its normal trade. The hospital operator tried to break out in September, failed, and has built a new base since then. The stock is now 21% off its 52-week high.
Several China-based stocks posted sizable losses.
Travel services company Ctrip.com (CTRP) skidded 4% in above-average volume. Financial software maker Longtop Financial Technologies (LFT) dived 9% and Yanzhou Coal Mining (YZC) slipped 4%.
Auto parts companies also dropped, as AutoZone (AZO) and Advance Auto Parts (AAP) both slid 2%.
11:15 a.m. Update: WEBHEAD: Stocks' Losses Accelerate

5:15 p.m. Update: The Nasdaq tumbled 2.3% and sliced its 50-day moving average. It had been above the line since March 23. Bellwethers Amazon.com (AMZN), Baidu (BIDU), Google (GOOG), and Research In Motion (RIMM) fell 3% each.
Despite a Merrill Lynch upgrade, Intel (INTC) reversed lower. LSI Logic (LSI) and Marvell Technology Group (MRVL), which also won upgrades, pared the bulk of their gains.
Meanwhile the S&P 500 gave up 2% and sliced its 200-day line. The NYSE composite also lost 2%, while the Dow fell 1.9%.
Volume dipped on both exchanges.

IntercontinentalExchange (ICE) tumbled 12% and sliced its 50-day moving average. The exchange operator slumped on news that the Commodity Futures Trading Commission is considering placing position limits on speculators.
Group mate CME GROUP (CME) lost 5% in heavy trade. It also breached its 50-day line.
Changyou.com (CYOU) reversed early gains and lost 4% in heavy trading. The Chinese online gamer was up more than 6% at session peak.
Valeant Pharmaceuticals International (VRX) shed 5% and closed 2% below a 24.47 buy point from a cup-with-handle pattern.
For Wednesday, the sole piece of economic data is the May consumer credit report.
After Wednesday's close, Alcoa (AA) will kick off the start of the Q2 earnings season. Analysts are expecting a loss of 37 cents a share on revenue of $3.92 billion.
4:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Close At Session Lows
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks stumbled and closed at session lows Tuesday.
The Nasdaq shed 2.3%; the NYSE composite and S&P 500 dropped 2% each. The Dow lost 1.9%.
According to preliminary data, volume rose on the Nasdaq and dipped on the NYSE.
Machinery, rails and select financials were the session's worst performers. Medical stocks bucked the trend.
3:15 p.m. Update: Comeback Fading In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks were back near session lows as rebound efforts faded in late trade Tuesday.
The Nasdaq and the NYSE composite dropped 1.2% and 1.1%, respectively. The Dow and the S&P 500 fell 1% each.
Volume continued to track lower across the board.
Cerner (CERN) lost 5% and breached its 50-day moving average.

Valeant Pharmaceuticals International (VRX) lost 4% and fell under a 24.47 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. The stock cleared the handle June 24. Earlier Tuesday, Piper Jaffray started coverage with an underweight rating.
2:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Rebound In Afternoon Trading
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks remained lower, but have shaved a chunk of losses.
The Nasdaq pared a 1.5% loss to 1.1%. Chipmakers Intel (INTC), LSI Logic (LSI) and Marvell Technology Group (MRVL) extended gains. Bank of America's Merrill Lynch upgraded all three.
Meanwhile, the Dow and NYSE composite lost 0.9% each. The S&P 500 fell 0.8%, but it bounced off intraday lows after testing its 200-day moving average again.
Turnover was tracking lower on both exchanges.
HMO's Aetna (AET) and Cigna (CI) jumped 7% apiece on reports that the Obama administration may delay plans for government-run insurance programs.
1:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Slump to New Session Lows
BY VINCENT MAO
Major indexes stumbled to new intraday lows in early afternoon trading Tuesday.

The Nasdaq dropped 1.4%, breaching its 50-day moving average. Heavyweight Google (GOOG) fell 3% to back under the 400 level. Apple (AAPL) and Research In Motion (RIMM) slipped 2% each. But chipmakers Intel (INTC), LSI Logic (LSI) and Marvell Technology Group (MRVL) bucked the trend, gaining between 1% and 3%.
Meanwhile, the NYSE composite lost 1.4%, S&P 500 1.3% and Dow 1.2%.
Volume was again tracking lower across the board, softening the blow.

Discover Financial Services (DFS) gapped down and dropped 11% following news of a stock offering. Late Monday, the company said it would sell $500 million in common shares. Proceeds will be used to repay the Treasury and for general purposes.
Perfect World (PWRD) dropped 4% to its lowest levels in over two weeks. The Chinese online gamer now sits 18% off a 52-week high.
On the upside, Community Health Systems (CYH) rallied 6% in brisk trade. The stock recently found support at its 50-day moving average. Community Health is shaping a new base.
Group mate Universal Health Services (UHS) climbed 5% and neared its 50-day line.
12:15 p.m. Update: Major Indexes Retain Losses At Midday
BY JONAH KERI
Stocks continued to trade lower at midday Tuesday.
The Nasdaq sank 1.2%, the Dow industrials 1.1% and the S&P 500 1%.
Volume remained lower across the board.
Web site hosting services provider Rackspace Hosting (RAX) lost 1% in above-average volume.
Steakhouse chain Texas Roadhouse (TXRH) shed 2%, yanking the stock further below its 50-day moving average.
On the upside, Changyou.com (CYOU) rose 3% in brisk trade. The China-based online gaming stock has traded in volatile fashion over the past few weeks. It's 12% off its 52-week high.
In commodities news, August crude oil sank 97 cents to $63.08 a barrel. Oil-related industry groups were moderately lower.
11:15 a.m. Update: Stocks' Losses Accelerate

5:15 p.m. Update: The Nasdaq tumbled 2.3% and sliced its 50-day moving average. It had been above the line since March 23. Bellwethers Amazon.com (AMZN), Baidu (BIDU), Google (GOOG), and Research In Motion (RIMM) fell 3% each.Despite a Merrill Lynch upgrade, Intel (INTC) reversed lower. LSI Logic (LSI) and Marvell Technology Group (MRVL), which also won upgrades, pared the bulk of their gains.Meanwhile the S&P 500 gave up 2% and sliced its 200-day line. The NYSE composite also lost 2%, while the Dow fell 1.9%.Volume dipped on both exchanges.IntercontinentalExchange (ICE) tumbled 12% and sliced its 50-day moving average. The exchange operator slumped on news that the Commodity Futures Trading Commission is considering placing position limits on speculators.Group mate CME GROUP (CME) lost 5% in heavy trade. It also breached its 50-day line.Changyou.com (CYOU) reversed early gains and lost 4% in heavy trading. The Chinese online gamer was up more than 6% at session peak.Valeant Pharmaceuticals International (VRX) shed 5% and closed 2% below a 24.47 buy point from a cup-with-handle pattern.For Wednesday, the sole piece of economic data is the May consumer credit report.After Wednesday's close, Alcoa (AA) will kick off the start of the Q2 earnings season. Analysts are expecting a loss of 37 cents a share on revenue of $3.92 billion.4:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Close At Session LowsBY VINCENT MAOStocks stumbled and closed at session lows Tuesday.The Nasdaq shed 2.3%; the NYSE composite and S&P 500 dropped 2% each. The Dow lost 1.9%.According to preliminary data, volume rose on the Nasdaq and dipped on the NYSE.Machinery, rails and select financials were the session's worst performers. Medical stocks bucked the trend.3:15 p.m. Update: Comeback Fading In Late TradeBY VINCENT MAOStocks were back near session lows as rebound efforts faded in late trade Tuesday.The Nasdaq and the NYSE composite dropped 1.2% and 1.1%, respectively. The Dow and the S&P 500 fell 1% each.Volume continued to track lower across the board.Cerner (CERN) lost 5% and breached its 50-day moving average.Valeant Pharmaceuticals International (VRX) lost 4% and fell under a 24.47 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. The stock cleared the handle June 24. Earlier Tuesday, Piper Jaffray started coverage with an underweight rating.2:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Rebound In Afternoon TradingBY VINCENT MAOStocks remained lower, but have shaved a chunk of losses.The Nasdaq pared a 1.5% loss to 1.1%. Chipmakers Intel (INTC), LSI Logic (LSI) and Marvell Technology Group (MRVL) extended gains. Bank of America's Merrill Lynch upgraded all three.Meanwhile, the Dow and NYSE composite lost 0.9% each. The S&P 500 fell 0.8%, but it bounced off intraday lows after testing its 200-day moving average again.Turnover was tracking lower on both exchanges.HMO's Aetna (AET) and Cigna (CI) jumped 7% apiece on reports that the Obama administration may delay plans for government-run insurance programs.1:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Slump to New Session LowsBY VINCENT MAOMajor indexes stumbled to new intraday lows in early afternoon trading Tuesday.The Nasdaq dropped 1.4%, breaching its 50-day moving average. Heavyweight Google (GOOG) fell 3% to back under the 400 level. Apple (AAPL) and Research In Motion (RIMM) slipped 2% each. But chipmakers Intel (INTC), LSI Logic (LSI) and Marvell Technology Group (MRVL) bucked the trend, gaining between 1% and 3%.Meanwhile, the NYSE composite lost 1.4%, S&P 500 1.3% and Dow 1.2%.Volume was again tracking lower across the board, softening the blow.Discover Financial Services (DFS) gapped down and dropped 11% following news of a stock offering. Late Monday, the company said it would sell $500 million in common shares. Proceeds will be used to repay the Treasury and for general purposes.Perfect World (PWRD) dropped 4% to its lowest levels in over two weeks. The Chinese online gamer now sits 18% off a 52-week high.On the upside, Community Health Systems (CYH) rallied 6% in brisk trade. The stock recently found support at its 50-day moving average. Community Health is shaping a new base.Group mate Universal Health Services (UHS) climbed 5% and neared its 50-day line.12:15 p.m. Update: Major Indexes Retain Losses At MiddayBY JONAH KERIStocks continued to trade lower at midday Tuesday.The Nasdaq sank 1.2%, the Dow industrials 1.1% and the S&P 500 1%.Volume remained lower across the board.Web site hosting services provider Rackspace Hosting (RAX) lost 1% in above-average volume.Steakhouse chain Texas Roadhouse (TXRH) shed 2%, yanking the stock further below its 50-day moving average.On the upside, Changyou.com (CYOU) rose 3% in brisk trade. Oil-related industry groups were moderately lower.11:15 a.m. Update: Stocks' Losses Accelerate

5:15 p.m. Update: A session primed by gains and policy moves in overseas markets, and dogged by weak consumer confidence data, sloshed back and forth before diving into an enormous charge into the close.

The Dow took the lead, sprinting 10.9%. All Dow components gained in the session, led by IBM ( (IBM) ), Exxon Mobil ( (XOM)), Chevron ( (CVX)) and Wal-Mart ( (WMT)). The S&P 500 rocketed 10.8% and the NYSE composite jackhammered out a 10.3% gain. The Nasdaq composite gunned up 9.5%. All but three Nasdaq 100 stocks gained ground, with Microsoft ( (MSFT)) and Google ( (GOOG)) topping the list. Small caps ran behind the pace, with the S&P 600 turning in a 5.1% advance.

Trading volume strengthened through the day, ending 29% higher on the NYSE and up 24% on the Nasdaq. The combination of healthy gains and solid volume led to follow-through days for both the Dow and the S&P 500, sending markets into a fresh confirmed rally.
In industry groups, 193 of 197 groups tracked by IBD advanced for the day.

Crude futures dropped a modest 49 cents in a third day of declines to below $63 a barrel. The December contract later rose $2.05 in electronic trading. Natural gas eked up 1%. Gold ended down slightly, while copper pounded out a 3% gain, following up on its 7% bounce Monday off a three-year low.

Trade school and private college educators bounced higher, led by DeVry's ( (DV)) 11% jump, up 5.21 to 54.21. The move put the technical school operator back above its 10- and 40-week moving averages in the sixth week of a cup-shaped base.
American Public Education ( (APEI)) popped 15%, up 5.25 to 40.08. The online educator regained its 40-week moving average, but remained below its 10-week line.
Strayer Education ( (STRA)) added a third day of gains, up 7.79 to 188.04. The stock is in the seventh week of a possible base, but faces resistance at its 40-week moving average.

On the downside, Whirlpool (WHR) weighed heavy in early trading and ended down 4.16 to 45.87. The nation's biggest appliance maker reported Q3 earnings of $2.15 a share, down from $2.20 the prior year, but 46 cents above Wall Street views. Sales edged up 1.3% to $4.9 billion, but fell short of views. The company also guided full-year income well below analysts' estimates, and said it will suspend its stock buyback program and slash 5,000 jobs by the end of next year.
3:15 p.m. Update: Dow Leads Late-Session Rally
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks gained strength in late trading Tuesday, as the Dow ramped to a new session high while other major indexes were close to doing the same.
At 2:42 p.m. EDT, the Dow was up 4%, led by gains in Wal-Mart ((WMT)), Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil ((XOM)). The S&P 500 rallied 3.9%, the NYSE composite 3.7% and the Nasdaq 3.2%.
Volume continued to track higher on both exchanges.
Rock-Tenn ((RKT)) rose 0.98 to 25.47, on pace to end a five-session losing streak. The packaging products maker reports earnings Nov. 4. Analysts see profit rising 47% to 84 cents a share.

Baxter International ((BAX)) reversed earlier losses and gained 0.74 to 56.41 in brisk volume. Earlier this month, the medical device maker reported a 26% rise in Q3 earnings and a 15% increase in sales. Both were the best in many quarters.

On the downside, Universal Health Services (UHS) gave up early gains, or 6%, and fell 2.38 to 34.38. That's its lowest level in more than five years. Late Monday, the hospital operator reported Q3 earnings and sales below estimates.

Bio-Rad Laboratories ((BIO)) lost 1.52 to 70.48 in heavy trading. But it bounced back from a two-year low of 64.40. The maker of diagnostic products releases earnings Nov. 6. Profit is slated to rise 3% to $1.06 a share.
1:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Rebound In Midday Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks mounted a comeback midday Tuesday but remained well off the best levels of the session.
At 12:43 p.m. EDT, the Dow was up 2.2%. The NYSE composite and S&P 500 gained 1.8% each and the Nasdaq rose 1.3%. Turnover was again tracking higher across the board.
Despite the improvement, there were few stocks rising in heavy volume.
DeVry ((DV)) rose 1 point to 50 and regained its 50-day moving average in fast trade. The for-profit school operator has been building the right side of a possible new base recently.

On the downside, Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) tumbled 5.66, or 19%, to a seven-month low of 23.40. Late Monday, the sports bar and grill operator delivered Q3 profit below views and cut its full-year growth outlook.
Thoratec(THOR) dropped 1.92, or 9%, to 19.76 in heavy trading. The medical device maker continued to sell off after announcing a recall Monday.
First Solar(FSLR) fell 8.56 to 99.35 in fast trade. It broke below the $100 level for the first time in 13 months. The maker of solar modules sits about 68% off a 52-week high.
Morgan Stanley ((MS)) and Goldman Sachs ((GS)) were down as much as 26% and 11% on market rumors but have cut losses by about half.
11:15 a.m. Update: Indexes Slip Into Mixed Trade On Solid Volume
An early surge fueled by energy and commodity stocks collapsed into mixed trade as surprisingly weak consumer confidence data dragged on investor enthusiasm.
The NYSE composite slipped from a 4% gain to a 0.2% loss by 11 a.m. The Dow fought to hold a 0.3% gain, the Nasdaq composite remained up 0.2%. The S&P 500 had edged 0.2% lower.
Volume was up about 18% across the board.

Moves in the large-cap oil stocks heavily influenced the early moves on the NYSE and the Dow. BP ( (BP)) thundered ahead 8% after Exxon Mobil ( (XOM) )  the Dow' largest component  added 4%. Heavyweight financial plays including Goldman Sachs ( (GS)) and Morgan Stanley ( (MS)) slipped lower.
Oil prices eked up 36 cents, holding below $64 a barrel. Natural gas blipped up a nickel, while copper and corn both rocketed higher. Bond prices and the dollar both lost ground.
In stocks, Strayer Education ( (STRA)) launched into a third day of advances, up 3.05 to 183.30.

Millicom International ( (MICC)) gapped up to gain 2.56, up 10%, to 29.07 after its Q3 sales and earnings results beat consensus views. The Luxembourg-based international wireless services provider has been correcting hard since May.

On the downside, Icon ( (ICLR)) crumbled 5.42 to 20, despite reporting a 47% increase in Q3 earnings, above analyst expectations. The drop drove the Ireland-based provided of clinical research services, in its seventh week of declines, to a 16-month low.

Overseas, London's FTSE 100 recovered from an early dip after BP's Q3 results sailed past analyst expectations. The index was up 3% in afternoon trading. Germany's DAX continued to power higher, due in part to BP and in part to the short squeeze driving Volkswagen ( (VLKAY)) shares to a second day of gap-up gains. The DAX showed a 6.8% gain in late trading.

October consumer confidence plummeted to a reading of 38, down from 61.4 in September and far below expectations for a reading of 52. The Conference Board reported the percentage of consumers expecting business conditions to worsen over the next six months climbed to 36.6% from 21%. The expectations index slumped to a record low of 35.5, down from 61.5 in September.
10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Rebound In Early Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks bolted out of the gate Tuesday, rebounding from recent losses.
At 9:56 a.m. EDT, the NYSE composite was up 4% and the Dow 3.8%. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 each rallied 3.7%.
Volume was tracking mostly even on both exchanges.

Amedysis (AMED) rallied 3.32, or 10%, to 36.01 after it delivered strong earnings and raised guidance. Before the open, the provider of home nursing services reported Q3 profit of 89 cents a share, up 46% from the prior year and 7 cents above views. Sales rose 78% to $321.6 million, also above estimates. The company guided full-year earnings in a range of $3.20 to $3.25 vs. views of $3.10.
Group mate Psychiatric Solutions (PSYS) climbed 1.90 to 29.29 in fast trade. It reports earnings on Thursday. Analysts expect 52 cents a share, a 37% year-over-year gain.

On the downside, Parexel (PRXL) gapped down and tumbled 4.34, or 31% to 9.36 after it posted disappointing sales and cut its profit outlook. Late Monday, the provider of clinical research services reported a 35% rise in fiscal Q1 earnings, beating views. But sales grew 26% to $263 million, missing analysts' estimates of $274.4 million. The company also cut its full-year profit outlook to $1.07 to $1.13 a share from previous guidance of $1.09 to $1.17.
9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Poised For Solid Open
BY VINCENT MAO
A rebound in global markets boosted stock futures Tuesday, pointing to a sharply higher open ahead of the start of the two-day Fed meeting.
Nasdaq futures rose 33 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures climbed 23 points and Dow futures surged 188 points.

After being hammered by recession worries, overseas markets bounced back. Hong Kong's Hang Seng rose 14.4%, it's biggest one-day gain in 11 years. Japan's Nikkei rallied 6.4% as it rebounded from a 26-year low. Germany's Dax climbed 8.7%, thanks largely to strong gains in Volkswagen.

The Federal Reserve begins its two-day meeting later today. To combat the ongoing financial crisis and stave off a recession, the central bank is widely expected to lower the fed funds rate to 1%. Earlier this month, the Fed cut interest rates to 1.5% in an emergency move among global central banks.

According to media reports, General Motors ((GM)) and Cerberus Capital Management have asked the government for $10 billion to facilitate a merger between GM and Chrysler. GM shares rose 10% in the pre-market.

Whirlpool  ((WHR)) reported Q3 earnings of $2.15 a share, down from $2.20 the prior view but 46 cents above Wall Street views. Sales edged up 1.3% to $4.9 billion, missing views. The nation's biggest home appliance maker also guided full-year income well below analysts' estimates and said it will suspend its stock buyback program. Whirlpool also will slash 5,000 jobs by the end of next year. Shares rose about 1% in the pre-market.
Thanks to record oil prices earlier this year, Europe's second-biggest oil producer, BP  ((BP)), delivered an 83% increase in third-quarter earnings. Shares surged 11% in the pre-open.

Zions Bancorporation (ZION) won preliminary approval to receive $1.4 billion as it entered into the Treasury's Capital Participation Program. The bank also cut its dividend by 26% to 32 cents a share.

On the economic front, the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index for October will be out at 10 a.m. EDT. Equity markets are closed Friday. As such, no notable companies are reporting until next week.
However, Friday at 8:30 a.m. employment situation data will be released. On Monday, non-manufacturing ISM data and pending home sales figures will be unveiled shortly after the open.
Volume Is Mixed As Stocks Make Gains All Around

Equity markets are closed Friday. As such, no notable companies are reporting until next week.However, Friday at 8:30 a.m. employment situation data will be released. On Monday, non-manufacturing ISM data and pending home sales figures will be unveiled shortly after the open.Volume Is Mixed As Stocks Make Gains All Around

5:15 p.m. Update: China's credit policy concerns, a stronger dollar and mixed bag of earnings and economic reports pressured stocks Wednesday. But the major indexes trimmed a good chunk of losses by the close.
The NYSE composite cut a 2.3% shortfall to 1.5%. But that was still its biggest drop in a month. The Nasdaq trimmed a 2.2% deficit to 1.3%. The Dow and S&P 500 fell 1.1% each.
Volume climbed on both exchanges.
AsiaInfo Holdings (ASIA) dropped 6% on nearly twice its average trade. The stock sliced its 50-day moving average.
Home Inns & Hotels (HMIN) lost 6% in heavy volume. The stock cleared a 38.10 buy point from a square box Jan. 4, but triggered the 8% sell rule seven sessions later.

Community Health Systems (CYH) shed 6% on three times normal trade. The Republican win in Massachusetts makes health reform seem less likely. This is bad for hospital operators that would miss out on new admissions.
Group mate Universal Health Services (UHS) lost nearly 6% on twice its average volume. The stock closed just above its 50-day moving average.

On the upside, Cree (CREE) gapped up and bolted nearly 18% to its best level since November 2000. Late Tuesday, the LED maker delivered a 90% surge in fiscal Q2 earnings and gave a bright outlook for the current quarter.
In after-hours news, Starbucks (SBUX) delivered fiscal Q1 results above views and raised its full-year profit outlook. Shares rose 2%.
eBay (EBAY) gained 3% after reporting Q4 results above views.
Earnings Thursday: Bottomline Technologies (EPAY), EZcorp (EZPW), Google (GOOG), Goldman Sachs (GS), Precision Castparts (PCP), UnitedHealth Group (UNH) and Western Digital (WDC).
Initial jobless claims, leading economic indicators and the Philly Fed index will also be out Thursday.
Stocks Finish Off Lows
BY VINCENT MAO
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks got hit Wednesday, but closed off their worst levels of the session.
The NYSE composite dropped 1.5% and the Nasdaq 1.3%. The Dow and S&P 500 fell 1.1% each. All major indexes were off by more than 2% at session lows.
Hospital operators and gold producers were among the worst groups. Super regional banks and some energy-related groups bucked the downtrend.
Stocks Cut More Losses
BY VINCENT MAO
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks continued to shake off losses in late trading Wednesday.
The NYSE composite fell 1.7%, up from a 2.3% deficit at its session low. The Nasdaq lost 1.5%, while the Dow and S&P 500 dropped 1.3% each.

A pop in the dollar hurt gold. The February contract shed $27.40, or 2.4% to settle at $1,112.60 an ounce. Gold miners lost ground. Iamgold (IAG), Jaguar Mining (JAG) and Newmont Mining (NEM) lost 6% each.

E-commerce provider eBay (EBAY) dropped nearly 4% in heavy trading. It will report Q4 results after the close. According to Thomson Reuters, earnings are slated to slip 2% to 40 cents a share. But sales are expected to rise 12% to $2.28 billion.

Starbucks (SBUX) erased morning gains and fell 2%, ahead of its own quarterly results after the close. The coffee giant's fiscal Q1 earnings are expected to perk up 87% to 28 cents a share. Sales are slated to edge down 1% to $2.58 billion.
Tech firms F5 Networks (FFIV) and Seagate Technology (STX) will also report quarterly results after the close.
On the upside, Lubrizol (LZ) added 3% to an all-time high. That put shares 7% past a 76.62 buy pint from a flat base.
Indexes Pare More Losses
BY VINCENT MAO
2:15 p.m. Update: Recovery efforts slightly improved in afternoon trading Wednesday.
The NYSE composite dropped 1.9%, Nasdaq 1.7%, Dow 1.6% and S&P 500 1.5%. Major indexes had been down more than 2% at session lows.
Turnover continued to track much higher on both exchanges.
Taleo (TLEO) fell 4%, wiping out Tuesday's move and then some. The stock cleared a 24.54 buy point from a cup-with-handle base Jan. 14, but is now close to triggering the 8% sell rule.

Likewise, MercadoLibre (MELI) dropped 4% and erased its Tuesday gains. The stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has weakened to D- from B+ in late December. Venezuela's currency devaluation has hit hard the South American e-commerce firm. MercadoLibre gets 17% of its sales from Venezuela.
Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) erased morning gains and slipped 2% in fast trade. The maker of robotic surgical systems reports earnings Thursday. Analysts see profit rising 35% to $1.71 a share.
Indexes Trim Losses In Early Afternoon Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
1:15 p.m. Update: Stocks were still down hard, but have eased off session lows.

The NYSE composite trimmed a 2.3% deficit to 2% and the Nasdaq cut a 2.2% loss to 1.8%. Meanwhile, the Dow and the S&P 500 fell 1.7% and 1.5%, respectively. Volume was tracking higher across the board.
A stronger U.S. dollar was hurting commodities. Gold tumbled nearly $30 an ounce, while oil slid 2%.

Dr. Reddy's Laboratories (RDY) shed 9% and breached its 50-day moving average. The stock had been trading above its 50-day line since September. Before the open, the India-based drugmaker reported a fiscal Q3 loss and cut its full-year sales growth forecast.
Harbin Electric (HRBN) tumbled 6%. It also sliced its 50-day moving average. The stock cleared a 23.01 buy point from a square box Jan. 5, but triggered the 8% sell rule six sessions later.

Brazilian homebuilder Gafisa (GFA) gapped down and fell 5% to a four-month low. The stock recently turned lower after hitting resistance at its 50-day moving average. Brazil's economy is expected to grow 5.8% in 2010.

On the upside, Amedisys (AMED) was well below its session peak, but still up 3% in heavy trading. The company inked a deal to provide home health care services to Humana's (HUM) Medicare Advantage members. Amedisys was up about 7% at session peak.
Aixtron (AIXG) gapped up climbed 3% in fast trade. The German firm makes equipment used to manufacture LEDs. It rallied in sympathy with Cree (CREE).
Market Down Sharply At Midday
BY JONAH KERI
12:15 p.m. Update: Stocks continued to absorb heavy losses in higher volume at midday Wednesday.

The S&P 500 slid 1.7%, the Dow and the Nasdaq 1.8% each and the NYSE composite 2.1%. Volume swelled across the board. It rose 14% on the NYSE and 32% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Tuesday.
Concern over China's plan to curb bank lending triggered selling in several leading Chinese stocks.
AsiaInfo Holdings (ASIA) tumbled 6% in more than three times its normal trade. The Chinese software and IT security products maker sliced through its 50-day moving average.
Home Inns & Hotels (HMIN) lost 5% in double its average volume. The China-based hotel operator fell further beneath its 50-day line after breaching it Monday.
Elsewhere, Blue Nile (NILE) sank 4% in above-average turnover. The diamond engagement ring vendor also fell further below its 50-day moving average. It's now 21% off its 52-week high.
Stocks' Losses Accelerate

5:15 p.m. Update: China's credit policy concerns, a stronger dollar and mixed bag of earnings and economic reports pressured stocks Wednesday. But the major indexes trimmed a good chunk of losses by the close.The NYSE composite cut a 2.3% shortfall to 1.5%. But that was still its biggest drop in a month. The Nasdaq trimmed a 2.2% deficit to 1.3%. The Dow and S&P 500 fell 1.1% each.Volume climbed on both exchanges.AsiaInfo Holdings (ASIA) dropped 6% on nearly twice its average trade. The stock sliced its 50-day moving average.Home Inns & Hotels (HMIN) lost 6% in heavy volume. The stock cleared a 38.10 buy point from a square box Jan. 4, but triggered the 8% sell rule seven sessions later.Community Health Systems (CYH) shed 6% on three times normal trade. The Republican win in Massachusetts makes health reform seem less likely. This is bad for hospital operators that would miss out on new admissions.Group mate Universal Health Services (UHS) lost nearly 6% on twice its average volume. The stock closed just above its 50-day moving average.On the upside, Cree (CREE) gapped up and bolted nearly 18% to its best level since November 2000. Late Tuesday, the LED maker delivered a 90% surge in fiscal Q2 earnings and gave a bright outlook for the current quarter.In after-hours news, Starbucks (SBUX) delivered fiscal Q1 results above views and raised its full-year profit outlook. Shares rose 2%.eBay (EBAY) gained 3% after reporting Q4 results above views.Earnings Thursday: Bottomline Technologies (EPAY), EZcorp (EZPW), Google (GOOG), Goldman Sachs (GS), Precision Castparts (PCP), UnitedHealth Group (UNH) and Western Digital (WDC).Initial jobless claims, leading economic indicators and the Philly Fed index will also be out Thursday.Stocks Finish Off LowsBY VINCENT MAO4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks got hit Wednesday, but closed off their worst levels of the session.The NYSE composite dropped 1.5% and the Nasdaq 1.3%. The first-quarter earnings season is unwinding fast with 87 members of the elite S&P 500 index already having reported financial numbers. Per the latest Earnings Preview, performances of these index participants indicate a 25% increase in total earnings on 10.7% higher revenues. The beat ratio is impressive with 82.8% companies surpassing bottom-line expectations and 67.8% outperforming on the top-line front.The Medical sector (one of the 16 Zacks sectors) is expected to deliver 9.4% earnings growth on 6.8% higher revenues in the first quarter. This is, however, shy of the projected 18.3% and 7.7% revenue and earnings growth, respectively, for the S&P 500 index.Healthcare is part of the broader medical sector, which includes diversified industries like health maintenance organizations (HMOs) popularly known as health insurers, clinical, laboratories and diagnostics research, medical equipment, hospitals & nursing homes, telehealth services and more. The sector is so diverse that a single factor influencing a sector positively can be a negative for the other sector. For example flu, which causes an increase in medical services utilization, is an earnings driver for the hospital sector while at the same time a negative factor for insurers it causes a spike in claim costs.  To put it into perspective, the January-to-March 2018 period was an unexpectedly brutal flu season, which led to a spike in medical cost for insurers. But because of UnitedHealth’s superior medical cost management, the flu season did not have any adverse impact on the company’s results. UnitedHealth is considered to be a bellwether for the other companies and its results provide a broad picture of the industry that despite increased flu, the first quarter will be profitable.The health insurers are likely to have witnessed an increase in premium and enrollment from the government businesses – Medicare, Medicare Advantage and Medicaid. A surge in the baby boomer population has led to higher demand for these policies. Earnings should also see an upside from ancilliary and health service businesses, which the health insurers have been investing in for the past many years to diversify the revenue base. These businesses which focus on data management, management of clinical records, analytics, clinical care, pharmacy care and more have been a nice contributor to the group’s earnings in recent years and the trend is expected to continue.However, this severe flu season should be a shot in the arm for care providers and other companies all along the pharmaceutical supply chain, as it would lead to higher revenues from increasing hospital visits and drug sales. Companies in the hospital sector should see increased patient revenues and admissions as more patients seek medical help, which in turn should drive their top-line growth.Nevertheless, the hospital companies should continue to feel the heat, from walk-in clinics and other outpatient treatment options that have been eating into their admissions volumes for past many quarters.Let’s find out where the following healthcare stocks insurers stand ahead of their first-quarter releases on Apr 25.Anthem Inc. (ANTM  -  Free Report) revenues have been consistently growing over the past several quarters, driven by membership growth. The company’s fully insured and self-funded memberships have boosted total enrollment. The Zacks Consensus Estimate for revenues is pegged at $22.5 billion, reflecting a year-over-year rise of nearly 1%.The company’s Government business has been performing well over a considerable period of time, supported by increasing Medicaid and Medicare enrollment. The consensus mark for total operating revenues of Government business is pegged at $12.8 billion, up 7% year over year.However, higher medical costs for individual ACA-compliant products and more claims leading to an escalated benefit expense ratio from its Medicaid business are expected to drain the bottom line.The Zacks Consensus Estimate of $4.85 for the yet-to-be-reported quarter reflects 3.6% year-over-year growth. Anthem carries a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy), which increases the predictive power of ESP. However, its Earnings ESP of -1.83%, makes surprise prediction unlikely as the company needs a positive ESP to be confident about an earnings surprise. (Read more: Anthem Q1 Earnings: What's in Store for the Stock?)Anthem, Inc. Price and EPS Surprise Anthem, Inc. Price and EPS Surprise | Anthem, Inc. Universal Health Services, Inc. (UHS  -  Free Report) is set to report first-quarter 2018 results on Apr 25 after market close. Last quarter, the company delivered a positive earnings surprise of 8.70%.Let’s see, how things are shaping up for this announcement.Universal Health’s Acute Care and Behavioral Health segments have been registering a strong performance over the past several quarters, on the back of a continuous rise in admissions, licensed beds and patient days, leading to higher revenues in turn.  The to-be-reported quarter is expected to have witnessed the same uptrend.The Zacks Consensus Estimate for total revenues in the first quarter is pegged at $2.7 billion, reflecting year-over-year growth of 5%.  Our consensus estimate for the metric from Acute Care and Behavioral Health segments stands at $1.5 billion and $1.3 billion, respectively, up 6.4% and 3.5% each, year over year.Since 2012, the average number of licensed beds in the Acute Care hospitals and Behavioral Health centers has been increasing. Our consensus mark for Average Licensed Beds in Acute Care as well as Behavioral Health is pegged at 6.2 billion and 23.3 billion, respectively. Each figure is up 1.5% and 1.2% on a year-over-year basis.An increase in the bed count at both the facilities will likely drive admission volumes.
